div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £ 9 to Brindisi.
The combined sea and special train fare has been reduced to £ 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Mersailles.

During the Monsoon season the express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.

FRIDAY, JUNE 9, 1905.

p.hi: FRANCE'S FOREIGN POLICY. The new Fronoh Minister for Foreign Affair will, we are informed, "uphold the Russian alliance, bąt will probably iosist on Russia guaranteeing that in fotore she will not take any action to jeopardise its utility, and will show herself more amenable to her ally's advice." These words are somewhat indefinite but they clearly show that Rassia's plight is a matter of serious preoccupation to her ally. France is traversing & real crisis. The late Baron Rothschild reckoned the amount of French capital sunk in Russia at eleven milliards of francs, that is to say, at more than twice the war indemnity paid by France to Germany. Now, however distasteful the alliance may be to the Republican spirit in the country, it is impossible for any Government to cut loose therefrom. Anything done politically wbich would weaken the hold of France upon the creditor, would be immediately hailed by the people as an aot of treachery. A Government that attempted it would inevitably fall, and perhaps the régime with it. Knowing that, and knowing, also, that if the war onds in the final humiliation of Russia, which is more than likely in the circumstances, the French people may whistle for their capital, and even for their interest, M, Rouvier's preoccupations may well be imagined. M. Deloassé endeavoured to stave off the evil day by supporting Russia to the utmost of his power, and by interpreting the neutrality question in a manner which, at least, did not embarrass the movements of Rodjestvensky. Apparently he thought by 80 doing that the Russian Admiral would regain the command of the sea. But he was deceived.

His successor evidently intends to adopt | plain speaking. That the French people feel deeply pained by recent events in St. Petersburg and elsewhere can hardly be doubted. They are a nation with a genius for civilisation. On the Continent of Europe it was they who performod the rough pioneer work of Democracy and they who struck the great omancipating
Individually and collectively they have been staggered by the superfluous ruthlessness of the Russian bureaucracy. It has wounded them alike in their consciences and in their
deepest political instincts. There is no country OBTI

in which during the late events the apolog. ists for absolutism have been so few and 50 tinorous. There is no country in which the denunciation of the Russian autocracy and its agents has been so spontaneous and irreprossible. The French have, indeed, felt in a special degree the ignominy of what has happened. They cannot quite acquit them selves, as the allies of Russian of all the responsibility, or at least of all the disgrace. They were never before so conscious of the gulf that separates them from the Russian Government. The realisation of this by the common sentiment of the French people is the immediate result of the St. Petersburg mas. sacre. It cannot, as some think, leave things as they were. It is bound, we are told, to have political results. And what those results will be is plainly stated. The weakening of the ties that bind Rassia and France in alliance is regarded as a probable, or even inevitable, consequence of the recent events and there appears to be a general expectation that the intense feeling of humiliation and repulsion with which France bas watched these events will loosen the corner-stone of her entire foreign polioy and create an atmosphere which will invalidate, if not dissolve, the Dual Alliance.

We cannot share this opinion, which seems to us to be based upon a very incomplete notion of what the Dual Alliance is and what it has accomplished, not only for France but for the peace of Earope. People have fallen into the habit of talking of it as a hopelessly one-sided compact. They have said that France has had to pay for it in gold, and that Russia has requited her with nothing but fine phrases. Gold has certainly passed, whether to the amount of two hundred, or four hundred, or
eight hundred millions sterling is a uninor and matter. Enough that the French have undoubt
edly subscribed handsomely to Russian loans 288) and invested with almost reckless confidence in six
Russian indastrial enterprises. But is it true
that fine phrases are the only or even the chief ber
reward the French outlay has met with? Is it not rather the case that France has some tangible benefits to show for her share in the
partnership 1 They might all be summed 1st up in a word, the word that Pitt used to

crystallise the one object of all others that Mi-| Great Britain aimed at in hunting down 2188, Napoleon, the word that the late Lord Salisbury 20. used as the goal of British policy in South :|Africa-security. France is secure, and not only
France, but the French Republic. The formation of the Dual Alliance removed once and for all the charge of political dowdiness that its
enemies, with a sure instinct for the foibles of and their countrymen, were continually bringing itor against the Republic. To be great, to bave a
position, they said, France must be monarchical. The alliance showed that Russia, and, following
Russia, all Europe, considered that the Republic ned

had come to stay, and had something worth having to offer by way of exchange. The moral effect of the alliance was worth at the time almost anything to the French. If people have at last got used to the idea of a Republic in
France, if the Republic has established itself the beyond doubt, the Dual Alliance must

largely be thanked for it. Internal peace must, therefore, be set down as one of the compensations derived from it by France. External peace it has yet more obviously guaranteed. There is, as things now are, no chance whatever of France being threatened and humiliated by any such movement as Bismarck is said to have meditated in 1875. The alliance removed the sense of helplessness ander which France was laboaring twenty years ago. These are two inestimable benefits derived by France from the alliance, and they are well understood by all close observers of Earopean affairs.

Nor is this all. France derives from the alliance with Russia advantages which no other Power conld undertake to provide. It is an excellent thing that France should now be on terms of cordial confidence with Italy and with ourselves. It is yet more excellent that after many years of anxiety, nervousness, and insecurity the Republic should now have entered the zone of hopefulness, and inspiriting baoyanoy. Bat it is doubtful whether Great Britain or Italy could possibly render to France one form of assistance of which she might some day be in vital need. It was until recently believed that that help could be given by Russia, and this was the belief ander which France entered the Dual Alliance. The question now is whether, in view of recent events in the Far East and in Russia, this determining consideration needs to be modified. Meantime it is evident that the Republic has gained by the Dual Alliance, both at home and abroad, and it is not by any means clear that the dissolution of the alliance would be & gain to France. She would be no; merely parting with an ally, she would be throwing into that ally's arms the very Power from whom she must always have the most to fear. We can only begin to gaage the preventive and deterrent efficacy of the Dual Alliance by imagining it at an end. Some thirty odd years ago Carlyle wrote : "That noble, patient, deep, and solid Germany should be at length welded into & nation and become Queen of the Continent, instead of vapouring, Vainglorious, gesticulating, quarrelsome, restless, and oversensitive France, seems to me the hopefullest public fact that has occurred in my time." Germany has become better known since then, and of the two nations we should not to-day say that it is France that is vainglorious, or restless, or quarrelsome. Those who expect the dissolution of the Dual Alliance should try and work out what its disappearance would mean to France, to Germany, to the present balance of power in Europe, and, therefore, to Great Britain,

div.head: RUSSIA AND PEACE.
div.p: As a result of a Council of Ministers held at Tsarskoe Sele, yesterday, instructions have been telegraphed today to the Russian Ambassadors at Washington and Paris that Russia is desirous of learning the Japanese peace conditions. (Reuter.)

Despite the prohibition of the authorities, the members of the Zemstvos sat the whole day. The speakers were unanimous in declaring that the nation itself must decide the question of peace, and reorganise the State. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE "SMOLENSK" AGAIN!
ANOTHER MARAUDING EXPLOIT.
div.p: The Russian auxiliary cruiser "Rien," formerly the "Smolensk," stopped the British steamer "Cilurmon" on the 2nd instant, 80 miles from Woosung, examoned her papers, threw overboard part of her cargo, and then escaped suspecting the approach of the Japanese. (Reuter.)

div.head: ORDERED FROM MANILA.
div.p: Admiral Enquist has been ordered to sail within 24 hours or disarm. (Havas.)

div.head: FRANCE'S FOREIGN POLICY.
M. ROUVIER'S PROGRAMME.
div.p: M. Rouvier will conduct the Ministry of Foreign Affairs till the questions pending are settled. This change will not affect the entente with Great Britain. M. Rouvier will also uphold the Russian alliance, but will probably insist on Russia guaranteeing that in future she will not take any action to jeapordise its utility, and will show herself more amenable to her ally's advise. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE MOROCCAN IMBROGLIO.
div.p: The comments of the newspapers attest the gravity of the imbroglio in Morocco. It is believed that M. Rouvier's first endeavour will be to find a compromise acceptable to Germany. (Reuter.)

div.head: KING ALFONSO IN LONDON.
MAKING AN EXCELLENT IMPRESSION.
div.p: In spite of the wretched weather King Alfonso is being greatly feted and is making an excellent impression by his gaiety and bonhommie. All official speeches on both sides are full of the friendliest expressions to the respective nations. King Alfonso lunched in full state at the Guild hall today. (Reuter.)

div.head: KHEDIVE LEAVES FOR PARIS.
div.p: The Khedive has left for Paris. (Havas.)
The match between Cambridge University and Gentlemen of Englan has been abandoned without a ball being bowled on account of rain. Sussex beat Lancashire by an innings and 215 runs.
The matches between Yorkshire and Australians, Northamptonshire and Leicestershire, and Somerset and Hampshire have been drawn. (Reuter.)

div.head: NORWAY AND SWEDEN.
div.p: The Norwegian Parliament has unanimously passed a resolution severing, the connection of Norway with Sweden, declaring that King Oscar bas ceased to be King of Norway, and conferring on the present Ministry the powers of government appertaining to the King. The address to King Oscar further declares that no ill-will is felt either to him or to Sweden, and asks his Majesty to co-operate in securing the selection of a young Prince of his House as King of Norway (Reuter.)
The Storthing has decided on the dissolution of the union with Sweden. It has asked King Oscar to authorise his son to become King of Norway (Havas.)
King Oscar has telegraphed to the Norwegian Premier protesting most emphatically against the action of the Government. (R.)

The action of the Norwegian Parliament in dissolving the union must either lead to war or to the acctptance of the situation by Sweden. The divergence of view is really of old standing, dating back almost to the earliest days of the union of the two kingdoms. That the possibility. of a conflict was foreseon from the first is evident from the declaration made by the first Sovereign of the united states, King Carl XIII., who in 1815 pointed out in a Royal "proposition" that “when two nations of their own accord submit to the same Government it is incumbent with the greatest care to avoid differences of any kind arising in regard to their relation to the common Regent. Otherwise the union sooner or later. will be broken, and either the one people will soon subjugate the other or their violent disruption will sow the seed of bitter dissension which may for centuries keep them apart.” In the case of Norway and Sweden no precaution which the circumstances of the time could suggest appears to have been neglected. The separate existence of the two States, united by the golden link of the Crown, was fully recognised, but the wisest of statesmen cannot possibly foresee and provide for every development which the future may have in store. In all their internal relations the maximum of freedom was secured, to each State to progress along its own lines. Each has its own legislature, its own laws, its own system of finance, its own methods of raising revenue and regulating its trade relations, both with its partner and with the rest of the world. Each, again, has its own Army and its own Navy, and it is only in their relations with other States that any serious difficulty has manifested itself. The Norwegians, with their Monarchical traditions, were content that the conduct of foreign relations should remain the prerogative of the Sovereign, but, when, in 1885, a change in the Swedish Constitution brought the conduot of foreign affairs more directly under the control of the Swedish Ministry, it is not surprising that a people so tenacious of their rights, and so ready to discern an attack on their status as a Sovereign State, should take alarm at what, viewed from the standpoint of Sweden, may have seemed a legitimate development of the constitutional principle of Ministerial responsibility. The controversy which twenty years ago assumed definite shape has been allowed to drag on ever since, while each successive attempt to arrive at a settlement has resulted in failura and has left behind it an increasing bitterness of feeling until now the aged King Oscar is face to face with the terrible dilemma of either having to begin what would be virtually a civil war or acqaiesce in the disrgption of Scandinavia. It is unfortunate that this contretemps should have occurred on the eve of the marriage of Prinod Gustavus, which is to take place in London this day week.

DR. ELMER LANSING.

It is with great regret that we record the death of Dr. Elmer Lansing, which occurred at the German Hospital, Cairo, on Tuesday evenFing. Dr. Lansing was well-known in his profession as a specialist in eye diseases, and his loss will be keenly felt by his colleagues and by his numerous friends. He was one of the oldest of the American residents in Egypt and for many years lived at Helouan, where his geniality and kindness gained for him a large circle of friends and admirers. The faneral service was held at the Mortuary Chapel of the German Hospital at 4 o'clock yesterday afterDoon and was attended by the greater part of the American colony in Cairo. Dr. Lansing leaves behind him a widow and daughter, who have spent their lives in Cairo and Helouan with him, and two song, who are at college in Amprica. We extend our heart-felt sympathy and sincere condolences to the bereaved family.
MRS. PONZETTA. - We regret to announce the death, which took place at her residence at Sohutz yesterday, of Mrs. Mary Popzetta. The funeral will leave Schutz Station. Magnin's House, at 3p.m. to-day.

THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL.

Oar Assiont Correspondent, telegraphing I yesterday afternoon, states that the acquittal of the accused in the Gbirgeh scandal case has caused general satisfaction. He adds that when the judgment was delivered cheers were given in Court.
The vernacular Press expresses it's satisfaction with the judgment.

TANTAH MUNICIPALITY.

The inhabitants of Tantah bave long been desirous of having a Municipality similar to those established at Mansourah and Medinet el-Fayoom, and in response to a petition to the authorities, authorisation has now been granted to form a mized Comiission.

The decree, which appears in yesterday's "Journal Officiel," says that "in view of the favorable results .obtained at Mansourah and Medinet el:Fayoum, by the system accordirg to which the inhabitants are called upon to co-operate in the improvement of their town by voluntary taxes... and in view of the request of the inhabitants of Tantah to obtain a municipal regime for their town similar to that in Mansourah and. in Medinet al. Fayoum... the inhabitants of Tantab are authorised to establish optional (facultatives) taxes on the merchandise exported or imported in their town, in order to meet the cost T of improvements in their town, the construo|tion of drains, lighting, drinking water supply,
filling up of marshes or other bygienio works, paving or upkoop of publio streets, and other i works of a similar character."
The decree embodies the constitution of the Commission.
GREECE AND EGYPT.

It is reported from Athens that the negotia tions between the Egyptian and Hellenio Governments relative to the new commercial treaty have not come to a satisfactory conolasion. The existing trasty will remain in force until March 31, 1906, i.o., for an extra period of tan months.
FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY.

div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT ).

Medinet al Payoum, Wednesday, I hear Mr. Davison has been sucomaful in the Mixed Tribunals in getting judgment with costs against the Fayoum Railway Company, and I trust he will not be long before he obtains another position, and one where he vill receive better treatment than he from his late employers. Mr. Davison hag during his residence here gained the good-will and esteem of the whole province for his straightforwardness, and both Mrs. Davison and he will be missed by many friends. This, I I think, is the second caso decided against this ! company within a fow worke.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.

p.hi: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.

div.p: (From our Correspondent).

p.hi: Suakin, May 81.
The railway line has now reached Sinkat, where it is intended to start the Kursals line, for which a big credit has now been granted by the Egyptian Treasuty.

Sinkat is a very healthy and cool station and it is proposed to preot a very fine Government Hospital there, on the lines of a hang togiom. All officers and Government officialswill be sent there from all parts of the Sudan As convalescents to recruit their health, instead of, as now, being sent to the Cairo military and civil hospitals. .

It is rumoured that both lines from the Atbara and Saakin will be joined by the end of September, 1905, but that it will not be open to traffic until the early part of 1907, in order to give the whole line time to consolidate, so as secure it against heavy rains and floods. All the bridges, numbering hundreds, will be completed by that time.
The British steamer Tabaristan” arrived here "from England on the 26th inst. with a special consignment of coal and other railway. material for the Sadan Government Railways.

The Khedivial mail steamer." Missir arrived here from Suez on the 29th inst. and landed the following new railway officials who arg to be employed on the Suakin. Atbara line : Mr. Albert Cree (of Alexandria), to take over the appointment of Traffic Inspector ; Mr. Hewson, Assistant Loco. Sape. rintendent, and Mr. Warn, engineer in charge of condensors. Mr. Warn has brought his wife and children with him.

It is with great regret that I have to record the death of Mulazim Awal Abdilmeghid Effendi Hilmy, Sadan Government Railways, which took place yesterday at his residence in Saakin, from appendioitis. He had been for some time in the Civil Hospital and was operated on by Doctorg, Orispin and Fahmy. Abdilmeghid Effendi was a member of the board of officers of the Sådan Railways here, and spoke English fluently. He was a promising young officer, and very much esteemed by all his friends. He leaves a widow and children hore. to 'mourn his loss. His funeral took place early this morning, and was attended by a large number of officers from the railways, the Moudirieb, and the 6th Battalion Egyptian Army. The firing party was farnished by the 6th Battalion.
It is also with regret that I have to report the serious illness- of Mr. Smart, chief storekeeper, Suakin-Atbara line, who has been laid up with high fever since the 28th inst.

The Sula II." of the "Commodore"in Clau I. "Walked” clean away from all the other boatų and came in an easy first, and therefore carried off Chitty Bey's cop. This boat will mae next week under the name of "Sans Paroille" u she has changed owners, and now belongs to Mr. H. de Teokadi. The "May" brought up the rear, and it is a pity that in doing so she should have forced her right-of-way with the winning boats of the other class n thereby she herself gained nothing and imporilled their chances.

In Class II the "Calypso" unfortunately crossed the line too soon and had to deturn and recross, thereby losing over a minute ; moreover she is not plaoed until the question of her forcing "Sala. II!" at the "black and white” buoy is decided by the sailing com.

After the races the 'Gumrook," with a "tais” in charge, anfortunately ran into the "Ironie” and Mr. P. Girard, vesy narrowly. escaped being injured by her bowsprit, bąt got off with a few bruises only

The finish of Class II. was a very pretty one, when seven boats crossed the lino within 14 minutes, thus showing a handicap which it. will be difficult to improve | Next week the regatta will start half an hoar later than the present starting time.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE

p.hi: COUR D'APPEL MIXTE
AFFAIRES D'ACCIDENT
Stelio Nicolaidis contre Bell's Asia Minor Steamship Company

div.p: La Cour vient de se prononcer sur l'appel interjeté par Nicolaïdis contre le jugement du Tribunal d'Alexandrie au sujet de l'accident survenu à bord d'an navire de la Bell's Asia Minor Steamship Company. En montant sur un escalier suspendu du dit navire, Stelio était tombé par suite d'une marche qui s'était brisée sous son poids.' . Dans son arrêt, la Cour adopte les conclusions des premiers juges et, tout en écartant l'exception d'irrecevabilité opposée par la Cie à la demande de Nicolaïdis, elle déclare cette demande mal fondée, parce qu'elle ne reconnait pas sufhsamment démontréo la nécessité de la présence de la victime à bord du navire et qu'en tout cas Nicolaïdis aurait dû prendre l'escalier ordinaire et fixe qui conduit an pont de commandement et non un escalier volant dont il ne connaissait pas l'usage.
ir Les Tramways d'Alexandrie

contre Emile Zananiri M. Emile Zananiri, revenant vers 10 heures da soir des bains du Mex, s'était heurté au mur peu élevé qui sépare le rivage de la mer. Il rendit la Vie des Tramways responsable de 8a chute, parce qu'elle avait omis d'éclairer le passage entre l'établissement de bains-rostaa. rant et la station, et l'actionna devant le tribunal mixte d'Alexandrie en paiement de dommages-intérêts. Il gagna á moitié son procès mais ne se tint pas pour satisfait et à l'appel principal de la Société des Tramways il joignit un appel incident.

La Cour vient de se prononcer contre lui; réformant le jugement de première instance, elle déboate Zananiri de son action en dommages-intérêts et le condamne aux dépens de première instance et d'appel.

Plusieurs motifs de l'arrêt méritent d'être retenus : D'abord, à l'art. 4 du premier contrat entre la Société et le propriétaire du casino aux termes duquel l'éclairage des locaux doit être fourni par la société il en a été substitué un autre longtemps avant l'accident pour remettre l'éclairage à la charge exclusive du locataire. D'autre part, la chute de Zananiri doit être attribuée surtout à sa propre inadvertance : car. en supposant même que la lampe placée à la sortie du casino n'aie pu projeter qu'une taible lueur jusqu'à l'endroit de l'accident, il est certain qu'en Egypte la clarté d'une nuit de septembre suffit à elle seule pour permettre de
voir son chemin sur un terrain sablonneux à un * homme qui use de l'attention ordinaire. C'est
d'ailleurs le premier accident de cette nature qui se produit depuis que les bains existent.
Les puits artesiens au Caire. Un confrère du Caire écrit :

Plusieurs de nos confrères ont annoncé que los pompes des puits artésiens installées par la Compagnie des Eaux & Rod-el-Farag ont commencé à fonctionner hier. Il faut entendre par par là qu'il s'agit des premiers essais, entrepris depuis quatre jours. L'expérience d'hier, qui consistait à nettoyer les nouveaux tayaux, & parfaitement réussi. La distribution à domicile de l'eau des paits artésiens commencera à partir de jeudi prochain, ainsi qu'il ressort d'une lettre que la Compagnie vient d'adresser au ministère des finances.

Les paits alimentant la ville da Caire sont au nombre de neuf. Leur forage ainsi que la construction de la nouvelle usine ont été effectués en quatorze mois, et ont coûté cent] mille livres, frais d'installations compris.

Ajoutons que seuls les immeubles recevant l'eau filtrée seront alimentés par les paits artésions. Quant aux jardins, il continueront de recevoir, comme par le passé, l'eau trouble de l'usine de Boulao.
BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE

(Anjourd'hui à midi et demie) La tension politique diminue en Enrope et l'espoir de la paix s'affirme davantage. Aussi la Bourse s'en est-elle ressentie: l'animation reprend sur toute la ligne, entraînant avec ello une hausse sensible des cours.
La Banque Nationale remonte de 26 9/16 à 26 3/4 l'ancienne et la Nouvelle est cotéel 26 7/8.
De même l’Agricole reprend de 13 11/16/P à 13 13/16, la Bébéra de 45 1/2 à 45 7/8, la Daïra de 28 5/8 à 28 11/16, et la Delta Light de 12 15/16 à 13 1/16.

Le mouvement sur les petites valeurs n'est pas le même ; l'Investment est un peu plus ferme à 1 11/16 et le Trust à 1 1/4, mais les Estates tombent à 15/16 vendeurs et la Salt and Soda de 35/6 à 35/3.
Le nombre des transactions a été considérable sur toute la ligne. La tendance générale est bonne.

p.hi: CANNUAL GENERAL MEETING.

The twenty seventh annual general meeting of the company was held yesterday under the presidency of Mr. A. C. Zervadachi, the chair. man of the company ; 18,404 shares were represented at the meeting, and from the report of the directors we note a continued increase in the company's business. The comparative table of the last two years working shows a total number of 15,473 services, with an increase of 1,327 as compared with the previons year. The total receipts were £73,375, with an increase of £5,276, and the working expenses were £22,925, or £431 less than last year. The quantity of water pumped during the yoår, for the town and Ramleh, was 13,653,166 cubic metros, being 466,175 cubic metres less than for the previous year. This unusual difference is due to the absence of rainfall during the season before last, which caused an abnormal demand for water daring the winter months, especially at Ramleh. During the summer months, on the contrary, there was a considerable increase during the last season. The construction of the new system of filtration is now in an advanced state, and up to the 31st March the amount spent on these works was £59,011, of which sum four-fifths are for the account of the Manicipality, in accordance with their convention. The company's system of pipes has been extended during the year by 8,084 metres of new pipes, laid in order to meet new demands for water. The amounts spent on new works during the year are as follow : The company's part of amount spent on new system of filtration, £11,597; engines, boilers, and buildings, £3,900 ; pipes, valves, and metres, £4,551 ; total, £20,048. The company's 8ecurities consist of £50,000 of 4 % Preference shares of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt, and £36,000 of Egyptian Preference Bonds. The directors have written off a sum of £1,550 as depreciation on works, which, together with the £29,000 already written off, make a total depreciation of £30,550 ; & sum of £300 has also been written off this year on materials in stock, and farniture, by the debit of profit and loss account. The balance of the profit and loss account to the 31st March, 1905, after the payment of the interim dividend of the 15th December, 1904, amounts to £38,964, and the directors recommended to the shareholders the distribution of a dividend of seven shillings and sixpence per share; which together with the interim dividend would form & total dividend, for the year, of ten shillings per share, and leave & balance of £1,464 to be carried forward to the next account. The meeting unanimously declared the proposed dividend and approved the accounts.

div.head: EGYPT'S NEEDS.
FEMALE EDUCATION AND SANITATION
div.p: A CONVERSATION BETWEEN ALY BEY OF SOHAG AND BUTROS EFF. OF ASSIOUT.
[ By A Native of UPPER Egypt. )
Butros.--Last time, you will remember, we woro talking about female education. Can you tell me what does the middle-class man do after he finishes his day's work bere in Assiout ?
Aly Bey.- What a question to ask ! You know well enough what your countrymen do every evening.
Butros.-Yes ; I know, but I want you to tell me.

Aly Bey.-Well, let us take a typical case. After bis work is over he will go for & walk on the Nile embankment with one or two of his friends. When they feel tired they go to & café, and there sit for two or three hours and sometimes more. They will play cards, dominoes, or what uot and order plenty of refreshments. At about ten o'clock comes the unpleasant task of going home. Whether he will have his supper downstairs in the madarah (a sitting room for men only) or upstairs, I cannot tell, but in any case he will have it all alone. Then comes bedtime, after spending what he would term & fairly pleasant evening
Butros.--I notice that you have not mentiuned his wife at all. Is he married or not?
Aly Bey.--Of course he is ; you know very well that it is extremely rare to come across O f Qurcountrymen who is not married. I
really do not see where the wife comes in at all. ..

Butros.-You have told me what the average Egyptian does, and I will tell you what the average Englishman does in London. As soon as he finishes work he diligently seeks bome. His wife welcomes him at the door. He goes upstairs and comes down neatly dressed. He loves to sit by the fireside opposite his wife and listen to what his children have got to tell him. After having & most enjoyable dinner he will, perhaps, ask his wife to kindly go to the piano (quite an unknown instrument here) and play his favorite pieces. When she has done that, she goes to see after the children and the house. He will go to his study, and in about an hour or two she will go and tell him it is bedtime. He will probably show her what he has been doing and consults ber about different things. Now which man of the two enjoys life most?
Aly Bey.-It is difficult to say, I know I should not like to spend all my evening with my wife. How strange ! you bave alluded to her no less than eight times and I did not allude to her once.

Butros.--Did I ? You certainly ought to have mentioned her more, because she is everything to the man. Most of the great mon in the West will tell you that their wives are of very material help to them. I have examined the English ways of living, and by comparing them with ours I find that we do not enjoy life a fraction of what they do. Life is full of blessings, most of which are to be found in the bome itself, and we lose thom nearly all
Aly Bey.-What blessings? I thought you Copts, professing the same religion as the English, would have the same blessings. .

Butros. -So we have, as far as the heart is concerned, and we honor and love our wives just like the English do; but the outward blessings of home-life depend chiefly apon our social customs, which are much the same as those of our Moslem friends.
Aly Bey.—You mentioned something about the husband going to his study. Surely men do not read books like school-boys, and have lessons to study.

Butros.- That is exactly where most of us are mistaken. We think that as soon as we finish school and college we have done with books for ever. This is a very great mistake, but it is a result of not having a home, for it is not possible to take books with us to the café or study in the mandarab, which is generally filled with friends in the evening.

Aly Bey.- That must be the reason why we do not produce great men. The educated classes kill their leisure time in useless occupations, --sometimes in harmful ones. The result is that they deteriorate, and we often wonder why they do not make their mark in their profession.

Butros.- I assure you, mon Bey; that the Egyptian will not advance to any appreciable extent until he has a home or, in other words, until his wife gives him one she is the only giver) and be lifts her to her proper position. Know this, mon Bey, that for thought, for improving the mind, for searching, for writing, for reading, for inventing, for ideal happiness, for innocent pleasures, for keeping away fron temptation, and for meditation we must have a home.
Aly Bey.—But surely you do not mean to say that we have no homes, for where do we have our meals and sleep?
Butros.- If you had seen an English home and stayed in it, I am sure you would quite agree with me. We can nover hope to have a
home in its true sonse, till we raise the woman to her proper position and educate her well.

Aly Bey.- I hope in ten years, when my son will be thinking of marriage, he will find a wife that will give him & home like the one you describe. I think it is quite unfair for our well-educated young men, who were brought up in Anglo-Egyptian or other Europ ean schools, to expect, them to marry girls who very often cannot write their own names.

Butros. —This is perhaps the most vital question to a nation. The Government onght to save half a million from what they have apparently dedicated for our railways and "urgent irrigation works,” and build us fifty schools for girls in the districts.
Aly Bey.--'These schools will want hundreds of teachers. From where do you propose getting them ?
Butros.--Have you forgotten England ? John Bull in his usual large-heartedness will send us as many of his daughters as we require.

Aly Bey.—That ought to work well, for we have a very great respect for the English ladies. The most narrow-minded Moslem, who considers it quite improper to send his daughter to school, will trust her to one of them. As for Arabic, we can always find teachers for that one subject. .
Butros.—The future Egyptian mother will owe her knowledge in hygiene and nursing to these English teachers. By understanding these arts, infant mortality will be greatly rednced in Egypt.

Aly Bey.—There is another reason which is far more important than the ignorance of mothers in this great calamity of the large percentage of infant mortality, viz., bad sanitation. Not only is this defect directly responsible for many dangerous maladies, but it is also most harmful in measles cases. A great authority writing on this subject says : - "Evidence points to the conclusion that insanitary surroundings increase the mortality.” Some doctors hold that they increase the liability to attack too. Therefore I do not think it is fair to throw the whole blame on the carelessness or ignorance of mothers.

Butros.-Grown-up people too suffer a great deal from bad sanitation. It is responsible for many fevers, it increases the death rato very materially, and when a case of cholera is iotroduced in Egypt, insapitary conditions develop it into a terrible epidemio. Sir Thome Thorne in his official memorandum of August 1892 says :-" Hence the sanitary improvements which would justify & sense of security against any apprehended importation of cholera, would to their extent, though cholera should never reappear in England, give ample remunerative results in the prevention of other diseases.”

p.hi: Aly Bey.-What we badly want is a sound corporation in each town. We have no drainage at all, we have bad water, poor and few lights by night, filthy streets, etc. I think the Government should supply us with funds, and appoint engineers and surveyors to commence the work.

div.p: Butros.—That is just like us Egyptians! What next? This is not a Government job. The administration has quite enough to look after. It is only natural that we should find our own good water, drain our dwellings, clean oyr streets, etc. • Aly Bey.-But surely you are not in tavor of introducing house rates? Why, even the Government itself does not think the time has come for local taxation.

Butros.- The Government is much too kind to us, and this extreme kindness cannot be good for us. They say "Spare the rod and spoil the child.”. In this case we are spoiling men. Don't you know that through its kindness and want of courage, we are in danger of becoming a mean nation ? | Aly Bey. - It is true that we are getting meaner every day, but I never thought it was due to Government leniency. It may be one of the reasons, but I think the chief is that our porse is developing faster than our moral and social positions. That is why I am not in favor of spending a lot of money on irrigation works at present for that will only mean richer lands and meaner men. Landowners and landlords have already much more than they want. In fact I do not know of any one of them who lives up to his income. I know one who has an income of L.E. 4,000 & year, and he spends about & couple of hundred, or 1/20th of his income. The Government should leave the land for a time and give it a chance to develop, and turn to the people themselves.

Butros.-It is appalling to think of the state of meanness we have come to. Two years ago Mohamed Bey's son passed his primary education examination. The son implored his father to send him to & secondary school in Cairo. He did; but when the son wanted to return last October to his school, the father would not let him, and he actually had the effrontery to say that he could not afford it, although his income was at least L.E. 1,500, and the son spent £60 in Cairo. | Aly Bey.-This is nothing. I know of cases far worse than that.

Butros.- Why are you not in favor of local taxation then? It is true, the Government will have to face a little "music," but what of that? It is equally true that the longer they I wait the louder this "musio" will be. When in

p.hi: a few years we see the incalculable good caused by the rates, then we sball bless those who bave imposed them.
Aly Bey.--Sappose we pay these rates, how are we going to manage our affairs, and have a sound corporation like those they have in England ? I au sure we shall get in a hopeless muddle.

Butros. -I am glad you admit our shortcomings. I think the best way to get out of the difficulty is for the Government to appoint an Englishman who will know all about corporation work. He will be the head of the council and director of all the town works. The surveyors, engineers, etc., which he may have need of will be paid from the rates.

Aly Bey.--You are very practical to-day, Butros, because you mean to give us a sound corporation. There is no doubt that if an Englishman is with as then we are quite safe. The only thing is that he will have to make himself quite at home and gain the confidence of the people. You know, it will not do to have an unpopular “Mayor."

Butros.-I am glad you are giving the English a kind word. Although some of us do not like their attitude towards the natives in general, yet no one in all Egypt can deny the marvellous work they have done, and if we hold our peace, "the stones will cry out.”
CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY.

From the somewhat bald announcement received from Bulawayo a few days ago that railbead on the Cape to Cairo Railway had reached a point 77 miles beyond Victoria Falls, comparatively few people realise how great & step has been taken towards the accomplishment of Mr. Rhodes' colossal idea of linking up the two extremos of the African continent. That great engineering feat, the spanning of the Victoria Falls, has been completed, the bridge has now been used for some time for the carriage of railway materials, etc., and the line will shortly be opened for passenger traffic. With every mile of railway northwards vast stores of wealth will become accessible. The Falls themselves are likely to become a very great factor in the industrial progress of the surrounding country, for it is intended to harness them and thus utilise the enormous power, hitherto completely wasted, for generating electricity capable of supplying the country within a very big radius.
RHODESIAN COTTON.

A sample of cotton grown from American seed near the Victoria Falls having been submitted to Messrs. Wolstenholme and Holland, of Liverpool, they report that they consider that if this cotton can be produced in quantity it will be an immense success, and state that "it classes 'strict good middling,' as compared with American staple 1 gin. in length, and is worth about 5d. per lb., as against 'middling' American, which is quoted at 4.61-100ths per lb.” .
VICIOUS VEGETARIANISM."

We hear so much of the virtues of vegetarianism nowadays that we are coming to think that living on nuts and granges is & short cat to the Nobler Life. It is refreshing, therefore, to read a serious and thoughtfal attack on the fad by Mr. William Archer. He does not take the humanitarian line of the party mentioned in Mr. Chesterton's "Napoleon of Notting Hill,” who protested against "shedding the green blood of the silent animals,” He denounces it as tending to lead the nation into &.condition of hyperaesthesia. If we examine the question, we shall see that there is a good deal of ground for this apprehension. Vegetarianism makes for a certain degeneracy. There is, as Mr. Archer points ont, a certain amount of nastiness to be faced in life. If we try to shirk it we become hyperaesthetic. The eating of meat contains an element of nastiness, if we look into it deeply enough. Mr. Archer confesses that he sways towards vegetarianism . when he is eating the last fragments of a helping of matton. "Clotted gravy on & cold plate” makes him long to live on fruit and other cleanly things. This, he recognises, is weak of him, and, if he yielded to the feeling, he would suffer morally. A vegetarian nation suffers morally, unless it makes up its quantum of nastiness in some other way. It any one wishes for an argument he should remember this.

div.head: GOOD MEMORIES
HOW IMPRESSIONS ARE STAMPED ON THE BRAIN
div.p: Memory is entirely a function of the nervous system. Its operation depends (writes Dr. J. Cater in "Chambers's Journal”) upon a facub ty which nervous elements possess of becoming modified by rearrangement of their molooular particles. Impressions reaching the brain are as literally stamped upon the molecules of the cortical nerve-colls as our foot prints are apon the sandy beach.

Imprints of the impressions thus conserved are available for future use as memories. And in consequence of the cerebral cells, nambering upwards of six hundred millions, and of their associated and conjoined action, the multipli

cation of possible imprints is practically withCoat & limit. The elaborate details of the process, the prodigions number of elements concerned, and the speed with which they operate, are no matter for surprise, seeing what the common fly accomplishes by rapid successive nervous actions.

It may be well to add that a normal exercise of memory presupposes an active circulation of blood, rich in material necessary for the integration and disintegration of the nerve-colls. When this is andaly increased there is a tendency to morbid excitation, and when it is de creased the tendency is towards & defective memory.

Therefore, effective conservation—that is, good memory-is assured by nutrition ; the registration of impressions constantly going on because the nerve elements are constantly renewed. The essentials of memory are thus associated with the fundamental conditions of life, and depend more largely than is commonly supposed on the mens sana in corpore sano.

div.head: TALKING TO ONE'S SELF.
div.p: Talking to one's self is generally considered & sign of a weak brain, says the "Family Doctor," but nothing could be a greater mistake. It is a sign of an extremely active brain. It may be a strong or a weak intellect, but the activity must be there to cause this peculiarity. If you will observe you will be astonished how many people you will meet in the street who are thinking aloud. The talking is done unconsciously.

div.head: National Bank of Egypt.
div.p: EMISSION D'ACTIONS EN AUGNENTATION DU CAPITAL SOCIAL

En vertu d'une délibération de l'Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire du 24 Mai 1905, le Conseil d'Administration de la NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT, met en souscription cinquanta mille actions nouvelles de la dite Banque, de dix livres sterling chacune, créées en augmentation da Capital Social, conformémant aux Statuts, et émises aux conditions bi-après.
L'émission est faite 80 prix de 20 livres sterling l'action payable comme suit :
ler versemant: £2.10/- à la souscription. 2me versement : £ 2.10/- à la répartition. 3me versement : £ 5 ls 30 Sept. 1905. 4me versement : £5 le 15 Déc. 1905. 5me versement : £5 le 15 Jan. 1906.
Tout retard dans les versements donnera lieu à l'application des dispositions des artieles 12 et 13 des Statutor
EN EGYPTE : au Siège Social, au Caire, et à la Sgcogrsale d'Alexandrie.
A LONDRES : l'Agence de la National Bank of Egypt, 4 & 5 King William Street.
Les nouvelles actions participeront aux bénéfices à partir da ler Janvier 1906, c'est-àdire à partir da prochain exercice.

Tout porteur d'aotions anciennes & du chef des actions par lai possédées un droit de préférence à la souscription d'une action nouvelle pour cing actions anciennes sans attribution de fractions. Les actions non sonsorites en verta de ce droit de préférence seront attribuées à la sonscription publique. *

Les porteurs d'actions anciennes qui voudront exercer lear droit de préférence devront d'ici au 8 Juin 1905 inclusivement, à peine de déchéance, faire leur souscription de ce chof aux endroits ci-dessus désignés avec dépôt des titres pår qux possédés et versement du montant du premier terme de £2.10 - par action.

Les actions non souscrites par les actionnaires en verta de lậar droit de préférence sont offertes à la souscription publique. Les motionnaires qui, indépendamment des actions par eux souscrites en vertu de leur droit de préférence, voudraient prendre part à la souscription publique, devront, de ce dernier chef, complir la formule de souscription spéciale à cet effet
La souscription sera olose, tant pour les actionnaires que pour le public, le 8 jain . midi et demi.
